1.heading: Law, Burton R.
1.title: A Gallery of Pen Sketches in Black and White of our Michigan Friends "as we see 'em"
1.author: by Newspaper Cartoonists' Association of Michigan.
notes: Detroit, W. Graham Printing Co., 1905.
"Compiled and collated by C. 0. Youngstrand."
Cover title: Our Michigan friends "as we see 'em."

Most of the caricatures are signed, and in the front of the book are photographic portraits of cartoonists A.G. Allan (Free Press), Fred C. Nash (Free Press), Fred I. Leipziger (Detroit News), Joseph Kraemer (Detroit News), W.W. Clarke (Detroit News), W.J. Baker (Detroit News), W.T. Bailes (Detroit News), B.R. Thomas (Detroit News), John J. Walsh (Free Press), Vera Casseau (Free Press), Burton R. Law, H.G. Berkey, Louis W. Tower, John F. Gilbert, Fred C. Hunt, Drury V. Haight, and C.O. Youngstrand.

13.heading: Law, Jude, 1972-
13.title: Road to Perdition [videorecording]
13.author: Dreamworks Pictures and Twentieth Century Fox present a Zanuck Company production ; producers, Richard D
13.appears_in: Zanuck, Dean Zanuck, Sam Mendes ; screenplay writer, David Self ; director, Sam Mendes.
notes: 1 videocassette (117 min.) : sd., col. ; 1/2 in.
VHS.
Cast: Tom Hanks, Paul Newman, Jude Law, Jennifer Jason Leigh, Stanley Tucci, Daniel Craig, Tyler Hoechlin.
Originally produced as a motion picture in 2002.
Based on the graphic novel by Richard Piers Rayner and Max Allan Collins.

Summary (from OCLC): Michael Sullivan works as an enforcer for his adopted father, Irish gangster John Rooney. When Sullivan's son, Mike Jr., witnesses one of his father's killings on Rooney's behalf, the gangster decides that his ward and his family are liabilities that must be removed. Sullivan tries to safeguard his son and get even with the man who betrayed him, while his son focuses on bonding with his emotionally distant father.

38.heading: Law.
38.title: "Special Agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation". First in a series. 7 p. in True Comics, no. 33
38.author: [No author]
notes: (3rd story; pages 8-14 of magazine; featured on 1/6 of cover)
SUMMARY: Covers the training of new recruit Steve Saunders. Firearms, deduction, laboratory work, and law.

NOTE: A notice at the bottom of the first page of each episode in this series reads: "This series is presented with the cooperation of the Federal Bureau of Investigation. The situations presented in this series are true, and the characters are authentic with the exception of 'Steve Saunders' who has been created as a typical example of the caliber of men who make up the intelligent and courageous personnel of the FBI." At the end of each episode is a letter from J. Edgar Hoover to the reader. 1. United States. Federal Bureau of Investigation. k. Training. k. Recruits. k. Firearms. k. Deduction. k. Laboratory work. k. Law. I. Hoover, J. Edgar. Call no.: PN6728.1.P3T7no.33

51.heading: Law and Comics.
51.title: "C'Était le Temps où la Bande Dessinée Corrompait l'Âme Enfantine"
51.author: Thierry Groensteen
51.appears_in: p. 14-19 in 9e art : Les Cahiers du Musée de la Bande Dessinée, no. 4 (Jan. 1999).
notes: (49-956 ou la Démoralisation de la Jeunesse : les 50 Ans de la Loi du 16 Juillet 1949)

English summary (from p. 142): "When Comics Corrupted the Souls of Children. From the beginning of the century, French educators have denounced the way in which comics distract children from 'real' reading. The image came to be seen as the root of all ills. Vulgar, ugly, violent, even pornographic, and confusing imagination with reality. Thierry Groensteen recalls the vigour of this crusade against comics, which was to culminate, in 1949, in the voting of a law (no. 49-956) that allows censorship of children's publications."
Includes excerpts of the law in question, and bibliographical references.

94.heading: Law Librarians.
94.title: "The Moat"
94.author: [No author]
94.series: Andy Panda) 8 p. in New Funnies, no. 98
notes: Summary: Charlie Chicken notices muddy water in the pipes, so Andy opens a pipe and floods the basement. They go outside to find the water main and shut it off, but end up digging all the way around the house before they accidentally break the main pipe. They end up with a moat, so they build a drawbridge. The mailman falls in, then two policemen, and a law librarian finds a law from the year 1591 against moats. By the time research is done and the police return, Andy and Charlie have filled in the moat. The tap water is still muddy.

225.author: by Dick Guindon.
notes: Summary: A passing voter holds a dialogue with a lawn sign ("Vote Ed Mertz").

226.heading: Lawn Signs.
226.title: "Found Some Firewood"
226.author: by Ralph Dunagin.
notes: Summary: He brings in an armload of lawn signs from the election.

227.heading: Lawn Signs.
227.title: "He Cut Across a Few Lawns"
227.author: Brad Anderson.
notes: Summary: Marmaduke comes home tangled in lawn signs.

228.heading: Lawn Sprinklers.
228.title: "Happy Fourth of July"
228.author: Johnson.
notes: Summary: The Fourth is shown as lawn chairs and a sprinkler, and fireworks.

229.heading: Lawn Sprinklers.
229.title: "I Have the Sprinkler All Set to Go"
229.author: by Bill Amend.
notes: Summary: Jason has the sprinkler under Paige's lawn chair, but Mom doesn't want the lawn watered.

230.heading: Lawn Sprinklers.
230.title: "I'll Have My Yaks When She Finds Out Who Actually Turned On the Water"
230.author: Neg Cochran.
notes: (Heroes are Made, not Born)
Summary: Concerns a lawn sprinkler under a lawn chair.

231.heading: Lawn Sprinklers.
231.title: "I'm the World's Best Lawn Sprinkler Runner-Througher!"
231.author: Schulz.
notes: Summary: Snoopy is disappointed that Lucy won't let him join the fun.
Original copyright 1969.

232.heading: Lawn Sprinklers.
232.title: "The Mailman Cools Off"
232.author: by John McPherson.
notes: Summary: The mailman has taken off his bag and most of his clothes and is jumping over a lawn sprinkler.

233.heading: Lawn Sprinklers.
233.title: "Only a Woman Would Ask That!"
233.author: Johnson.
notes: Janis wonders why Arlo doesn't just turn the sprinkler off when he moves it.

234.heading: Lawn Sprinklers.
234.title: "Ride Right Over It, Chum!"
234.author: by Walt Disney.
notes: Summary: A man has his lawn sprinkler and hose on the sidewalk; Donald replaces is front bicycle wheel with a rotary saw blade before he rides over it.

235.heading: Lawn Sprinklers.
235.title: "A Tunnel Linking Europe to Denver"
235.author: by Scott Adams.
notes: Summary: The pointy-haired boss had to top another manager's remark about his sprinkler system, and a press release resulted.

236.heading: Lawn Sprinklers.
236.title: "You Combine a Spray Painter and a Lawn Sprinkler"
236.author: Blazek & Truxaw.
notes: Summary: A patient says he's actually painting his living room at the same time he's talking to Dr. Katz.

237.title: "The Lawn that Devoured Cleveland"
237.author: David Michelinie, script ; Sergio Aragones, art

238.heading: Lawn Tools.
238.title: "And I Thought a Weed Eater was a Lawn Tool"
238.author: Sinclair.

publication info.place: Reprinted on p. 37 in Alex's Restaurant (Freedom, Ca.

notes: Summary: The restaurant has labeled the edible wild plants in the yard, for a fresh organic salad bar.

239.heading: Lawn Tractors.
239.title: "It's a Good Will Tour"
239.author: Russell Myers.
notes: Summary: They're driving coast to coast on a lawn tractor, in the fast lane at 3 mph.

notes:
